## AIæ™‚ä»£ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³

Googleã®æŠ€è¡“ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ™ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã§ã‚ã‚‹[Jigsawï¼ˆã‚¸ã‚°ã‚½ãƒ¼ï¼‰](https://jigsaw.google/)ãŒã€2025å¹´ã«ã€Œ[Facilitation in the AI Eraï¼ˆAIæ™‚ä»£ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ï¼‰](https://services.google.com/fh/files/blogs/jigsaw_facilitation_in_the_ai_era.pdf)ã€ã¨é¡Œã™ã‚‹ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’å…¬é–‹ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

Jigsawã¯2011å¹´ã«Google Ideasã¨ã—ã¦è¨­ç«‹ã•ã‚Œã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ãªç¤¾ä¼šã¸ã®è„…å¨ã«å¯¾ã—ã¦æŠ€è¡“ã§ç«‹ã¡å‘ã‹ã†ã“ã¨ã‚’ä½¿å‘½ã¨ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚æ¤œé–²ã‚’å›é¿ã™ã‚‹VPNãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã€ŒOutlineã€ã¯æœˆé–“3,000ä¸‡äººä»¥ä¸Šã«åˆ©ç”¨ã•ã‚Œã€DDoSæ”»æ’ƒã‹ã‚‰ç‹¬ç«‹ãƒ¡ãƒ‡ã‚£ã‚¢ã‚’å®ˆã‚‹ã€ŒProject Shieldã€ã€ã‚ªãƒ³ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ³ã®æœ‰å®³ã‚³ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚’æ¤œå‡ºã™ã‚‹ã€ŒPerspective APIã€ã¯18è¨€èªã§ä¸€æ—¥ã‚ãŸã‚Šç´„20å„„å›åˆ©ç”¨ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãªã©ã€å¸‚æ°‘ç¤¾ä¼šã‚’æ”¯ãˆã‚‹ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’æ•°å¤šãé–‹ç™ºãƒ»å…¬é–‹ã—ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

ãã®JigsawãŒè¿‘å¹´ã€åŠ›ã‚’å…¥ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ãŒã€Œå¸‚æ°‘å¯¾è©±ã€ã¨ã€ŒAIã€ã®äº¤å·®ç‚¹ã§ã™ã€‚æ•°åƒäººã€æ•°ä¸‡äººã®å£°ã‚’ã©ã†ã‚„ã£ã¦è´ãã€æ§‹é€ åŒ–ã—ã€æ„æ€æ±ºå®šã«æ¥ç¶šã™ã‚‹ã‹ã€‚ã“ã®å•ã„ã«æ­£é¢ã‹ã‚‰å–ã‚Šçµ„ã‚“ã ã®ãŒæœ¬ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã‚ã‚Šã€åŒæ™‚ã«å…¬é–‹ã•ã‚ŒãŸã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ç¾¤ã§ã™ã€‚

### ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆãŒç¤ºã—ãŸ5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸ

![ã€ŒFacilitation in the AI Eraã€ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆè¡¨ç´™](../images/column_jigsaw_cover.png)

ã€ŒFacilitation in the AI Eraã€ã¯ã€Jigsawã®ç ”ç©¶è€…ãŒä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°ã®22äººã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã¨å…±åŒã§ä½œæˆã—ãŸã‚‚ã®ã§ã™ã€‚å˜ãªã‚‹æŠ€è¡“ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã¯ãªãã€ç¾å ´ã§å¸‚æ°‘å¯¾è©±ã‚’é€²è¡Œã—ã¦ããŸãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãŸã¡ã®å£°ã‚’ä¸å¯§ã«æ‹¾ã„ä¸Šã’ãŸå®Ÿè·µçš„ãªæ–‡æ›¸ã¨ã—ã¦è¨­è¨ˆã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®æ ¸å¿ƒã«ã‚ã‚‹ãƒ¡ãƒƒã‚»ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã¯æ˜å¿«ã§ã™ã€‚AIã¯ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚’ã€Œç½®ãæ›ãˆã‚‹ã€ã‚‚ã®ã§ã¯ãªãã€äººã€…ã®structural agencyï¼ˆæ§‹é€ çš„ä¸»ä½“æ€§ï¼‰ã‚’å¼·åŒ–ã™ã‚‹ã‚‚ã®ã ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã€‚ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã€ã€Œè‡ªåˆ†ã®å£°ãŒç¤¾ä¼šã«å±Šãã€ã¨ã„ã†å®Ÿæ„Ÿã‚’ã€ã‚ˆã‚Šå¤šãã®äººã«å±Šã‘ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã®æŠ€è¡“ã¨ã—ã¦AIã‚’ä½ç½®ã¥ã‘ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã¯ã€ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã‚’ã€Œä¼šè­°å‰ï¼ˆBEFOREï¼‰ã€ã€Œä¼šè­°ä¸­ï¼ˆDURINGï¼‰ã€ã€Œä¼šè­°å¾Œï¼ˆAFTERï¼‰ã€ã®3æ®µéšã«åˆ†ã‘ã€AIãŒæ”¯æ´ã§ãã‚‹5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸãŒæç¤ºã•ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

![ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆãŒæç¤ºã—ãŸ5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸ](../images/column_jigsaw_opportunity_areas.png)

**ä¼šè­°å‰ï¼ˆBEFOREï¼‰**

1. **Scaled Accessï¼ˆã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ©ãƒ–ãƒ«ãªã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ï¼‰**ï¼šå¤šè¨€èªå¯¾å¿œã‚„ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚²ãƒƒãƒˆã«åˆã‚ã›ãŸã‚¢ã‚¦ãƒˆãƒªãƒ¼ãƒã«ã‚ˆã‚Šã€ã‚ˆã‚Šå¤šæ§˜ãªå‚åŠ è€…ã‚’å¯¾è©±ã«æ‹›ãå…¥ã‚Œã‚‹
2. **Dynamic Learningï¼ˆãƒ€ã‚¤ãƒŠãƒŸãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãƒ‹ãƒ³ã‚°ï¼‰**ï¼šãƒãƒ«ãƒãƒ¢ãƒ¼ãƒ€ãƒ«ãªãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’æ´»ç”¨ã—ã€å‚åŠ è€…ãŒã‚¨ãƒ“ãƒ‡ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’ç™ºè¦‹ãƒ»å­¦ç¿’ã§ãã‚‹ç’°å¢ƒã‚’æ•´ãˆã‚‹

**ä¼šè­°ä¸­ï¼ˆDURINGï¼‰**

3. **Live Sensemakingï¼ˆãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ã‚»ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒ¡ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ³ã‚°ï¼‰**ï¼šå¯¾è©±ã®ãƒªã‚¢ãƒ«ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ åˆ†æã¨å¯è¦–åŒ–ã‚’è¡Œã„ã€è­°è«–ã®æ§‹é€ ã‚’å³åº§ã«æŠŠæ¡ã™ã‚‹

## AIæ™‚ä»£ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³

ãã®JigsawãŒè¿‘å¹´ã€åŠ›ã‚’å…¥ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ãŒã€Œå¸‚æ°‘å¯¾è©±ã€ã¨ã€ŒAIã€ã®äº¤å·®ç‚¹ã§ã™ã€‚æ•°åƒäººã€æ•°ä¸‡äººã®å£°ã‚’ã©ã†ã‚„ã£ã¦è´ãã€æ§‹é€ åŒ–ã—ã€æ„æ€æ±ºå®šã«æ¥ç¶šã™ã‚‹ã‹ã€‚ã“ã®å•ã„ã«æ­£é¢ã‹ã‚‰å–ã‚Šçµ„ã‚“ã ã®ãŒæœ¬ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã‚ã‚Šã€åŒæ™‚ã«å…¬é–‹ã•ã‚ŒãŸã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ç¾¤ã§ã™ã€‚

### ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆãŒç¤ºã—ãŸ5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸ

![ã€ŒFacilitation in the AI Eraã€ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆè¡¨ç´™](../images/column_jigsaw_cover.png)

ã€ŒFacilitation in the AI Eraã€ã¯ã€Jigsawã®ç ”ç©¶è€…ãŒä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°ã®22äººã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã¨å…±åŒã§ä½œæˆã—ãŸã‚‚ã®ã§ã™ã€‚å˜ãªã‚‹æŠ€è¡“ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã¯ãªãã€ç¾å ´ã§å¸‚æ°‘å¯¾è©±ã‚’é€²è¡Œã—ã¦ããŸãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãŸã¡ã®å£°ã‚’ä¸å¯§ã«æ‹¾ã„ä¸Šã’ãŸå®Ÿè·µçš„ãªæ–‡æ›¸ã¨ã—ã¦è¨­è¨ˆã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®æ ¸å¿ƒã«ã‚ã‚‹ãƒ¡ãƒƒã‚»ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã¯æ˜å¿«ã§ã™ã€‚AIã¯ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚’ã€Œç½®ãæ›ãˆã‚‹ã€ã‚‚ã®ã§ã¯ãªãã€äººã€…ã®structural agencyï¼ˆæ§‹é€ çš„ä¸»ä½“æ€§ï¼‰ã‚’å¼·åŒ–ã™ã‚‹ã‚‚ã®ã ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã€‚ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã€ã€Œè‡ªåˆ†ã®å£°ãŒç¤¾ä¼šã«å±Šãã€ã¨ã„ã†å®Ÿæ„Ÿã‚’ã€ã‚ˆã‚Šå¤šãã®äººã«å±Šã‘ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã®æŠ€è¡“ã¨ã—ã¦AIã‚’ä½ç½®ã¥ã‘ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ã¯ã€ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã‚’ã€Œä¼šè­°å‰ï¼ˆBEFOREï¼‰ã€ã€Œä¼šè­°ä¸­ï¼ˆDURINGï¼‰ã€ã€Œä¼šè­°å¾Œï¼ˆAFTERï¼‰ã€ã®3æ®µéšã«åˆ†ã‘ã€AIãŒæ”¯æ´ã§ãã‚‹5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸãŒæç¤ºã•ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

![ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆãŒæç¤ºã—ãŸ5ã¤ã®æ©Ÿä¼šé ˜åŸŸ](../images/column_jigsaw_opportunity_areas.png)

**ä¼šè­°å‰ï¼ˆBEFOREï¼‰**

1. **Scaled Accessï¼ˆã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ©ãƒ–ãƒ«ãªã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ï¼‰**ï¼šå¤šè¨€èªå¯¾å¿œã‚„ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚²ãƒƒãƒˆã«åˆã‚ã›ãŸã‚¢ã‚¦ãƒˆãƒªãƒ¼ãƒã«ã‚ˆã‚Šã€ã‚ˆã‚Šå¤šæ§˜ãªå‚åŠ è€…ã‚’å¯¾è©±ã«æ‹›ãå…¥ã‚Œã‚‹

**ä¼šè­°å¾Œï¼ˆAFTERï¼‰**

4. **Futurecastingï¼ˆãƒ•ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ£ã‚¹ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ³ã‚°ï¼‰**ï¼šã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ‹ãƒ³ã‚°ã¨å¤–æŒ¿ã«ã‚ˆã‚Šã€è­°è«–ã®çµæœã‚’å°†æ¥ã®è¨ˆç”»ã«æ¥ç¶šã™ã‚‹
5. **Sensemaking For The Peopleï¼ˆå¸‚æ°‘ã®ãŸã‚ã®ã‚»ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒ¡ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ³ã‚°ï¼‰**ï¼šã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ–ãªå…¬é–‹åˆ†æã¨ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ³ã‚°ã§ã€çµæœã‚’å¸‚æ°‘ã«é‚„å…ƒã™ã‚‹

ã„ãšã‚Œã«ã‚‚å…±é€šã™ã‚‹ã®ã¯ã€ã€ŒAIãŒãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚’æ•´ç†ã—ã€äººé–“ãŒæ–‡è„ˆã®ä¸­ã§è§£é‡ˆã™ã‚‹ã€ã¨ã„ã†å½¹å‰²åˆ†æ‹…ã®åŸå‰‡ã§ã™ã€‚AIã¯åŠ¹ç‡çš„ã«ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚’åˆ†é¡ãƒ»æ•´ç†ã™ã‚‹ä¸€æ–¹ã€äººé–“ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãŒç¤¾ä¼šçš„ãƒ»åœ°ç†çš„ãªæ–‡è„ˆã®ä¸­ã§ãã®ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚’è§£é‡ˆã—ã€æœ€çµ‚çš„ãªåˆ¤æ–­ã‚’ä¸‹ã™ã€‚ã“ã®åˆ†æ¥­ã“ããŒã€ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆå…¨ä½“ã‚’è²«ãè¨­è¨ˆæ€æƒ³ã§ã™ã€‚

Links: [{"title":"Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication: Augmenting Human-Human Text Chat through LLM-based Adaptive Agent Pair","url":"https://arxiv.org/html/2502.18201v1"},{"title":"Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication:","url":"https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.18201"},{"title":"[2502.18201] Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication: Augmenting Human-Human Text Chat through LLM-based Adaptive Agent Pair","url":"https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.18201"},{"title":"AI-Mediated Communication: Language Use and Interpersonal Effects in a Referential Communication Task | Request PDF","url":"https://www.researchgate.REDACTED"},{"title":"dblp: Shutaro Aoyama","url":"https://dblp.org/pid/332/1395.html"},{"title":"Shutaro Aoyama - Research Assistant - Sony Computer Science Laboratories | LinkedIn","url":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/shutaro-aoyama-11a387176/"},{"title":"AI-Mediated Communication: How the Perception that Profile Text was Written by AI Affects Trustworthiness","url":"https://www.researchgate.REDACTED"},{"title":"Papers | IEEE VR 2024","url":"https://ieeevr.org/2024/program/papers/"},{"title":"2024 IEEE Conference Virtual Reality and 3D User ...","url":"https://www.proceedings.com/content/074/074281webtoc.pdf"},{"title":"Table of Contents - 2024 IEEE International Conference on ...","url":"https://www.computer.org/csdl/proceedings/aixvr/2024/1UUdPW7WJji"}]

I found search results related to your query. Here are the key findings:

Shutaro Aoyama is from Columbia University, and he proposed the Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication, an alternative communication model that leverages LLM-based adaptive agents to augment human-human communication.

In the Intersubjective Model, individuals do not share a common environment; instead, they engage in conversations with AI agents within independent chat environments, where communication between humans occurs indirectly through information sharing between these AI agents. Unlike traditional communication models that focus on the accurate transmission of information, the Intersubjective Model allows for communication to be designed in an adaptive and customizable way to create alternative interactions by dynamically shaping messages in real time.

The research appears to be documented in an arXiv paper (arXiv:2502.18201). Additionally, Aoyama presented work on an asynchronous VR interface for high-level robot teleoperation at IEEE VR 2024.

Cybernetic Humanity is a new research field that focuses on the "new humanity" emerged from the integration of humans and computers, and explores it through approaches from both computer science and human science, advocated by Dr. Shunichi Kasahara.

Shunichi Kasahara serves as a project leader and researcher at Sony Computer Science Laboratories, Inc. (Sony CSL) since 2014, and is also a visiting researcher at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology Graduate University (OIST) from 2023 for running Cybernetic Humanity Studioâ€”a collaboration between Sony CSL and OIST.

The research focuses on the dynamics of humanity woven by the integration of humans and computers from multifaceted perspectives which includes augmented sensation and perception as fundamental elements that constitute embodiment, 'self' through extended cognition, and "social self," which is formed through interaction and relationships with others.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Shutaro Aoyama:

Shutaro Aoyama worked as a Research Assistant at Sony Computer Science Laboratories and the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology, where their work aimed to contribute to the future of humanity and the planet through areas such as human augmentation, creativity, and sustainable societal development.

Beyond Sony CSL, Shutaro collaborated with the Naemura Lab at the University of Tokyo and served as an Undergraduate Researcher in the CGUI Lab at Columbia University. Additionally, Shutaro Aoyama pursued a Bachelor of Science degree at Columbia University.

The professional background also includes work as a Full Stack Engineer & Intern at Helpfeel, and served as the Kineto Project Leader within the Mitou Incubator Program.

Shutaro Aoyama is studying Computer Science and Philosophy at Columbia University. He was selected as an Egleston Scholar, the top 1% of Columbia Engineering student.

content.content:
# Paper Summary: Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication

**Title:** Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication: Augmenting Human-Human Text Chat through LLM-based Adaptive Agent Pair

**Authors:** Shutaro Aoyama, Rintaro Chujo, Ari Hautasaari, Takeshi Naemura

**Venue:** Computer Science > Human-Computer Interaction (arXiv:2502.18201)

**Submission Date:** February 25, 2025

## Abstract Summary

The researchers propose a novel framework departing from traditional communication models. Rather than treating LLMs as passive tools, their approach uses "LLM-based adaptive agents to augment human-human communication." The system dynamically transforms messages in real-time to "facilitate shared understanding between the human participants."

## Key Contributions

1. **New Communication Model:** Introduces an alternative to traditional transmission-focused models that emphasizes adaptive, customizable interaction design

2. **Prototype Development:** Created a text chat system demonstrating the model's practical potential

3. **Design Space Exploration:** Maps out how AI can reshape message dynamics rather than simply relay information between users

The work represents a shift in thinking about AI-mediated communicationâ€”moving beyond LLMs as message relayers to active participants that reshape dialogue to enhance mutual comprehension.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about these connections:

## Shutaro Aoyama

Shutaro Aoyama worked as a Research Assistant at Sony Computer Science Laboratories and the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology. He also collaborated with the Naemura Lab at the University of Tokyo and served as an Undergraduate Researcher at the CGUI Lab at Columbia University. Aoyama is pursuing a Bachelor of Science degree at Columbia University.

## The Kasahara Lab & Cybernetic Humanity

Dr. Shunichi Kasahara is a visiting researcher at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology Graduate University (OIST) from 2023, running the Cybernetic Humanity Studioâ€”a collaboration between Sony CSL and OIST.

Cybernetic Humanity is a new research field that focuses on the "new humanity" emerged from the integration of humans and computers, and explores it through approaches from both computer science and human science, advocated by Dr. Shunichi Kasahara. The research focuses on augmenting perception, cognition, and embodiment, elucidating the 'self' through subjective experiences and understanding the dynamics of humanity that are woven by the integration of humans and computers.

Digital Democracy 2030 is a nonprofit, neutral OSS development community in Japan that uses AI and digital technology to address structural issues like information fragmentation and political participation gaps, building mechanisms to increase transparency in policy formation and expand participation.

# Plurality Tokyo Namerakaigi #2 Event Details

## Event Information
**Date & Time:** Saturday, May 10, 2025, 1:00 PM â€“ 6:15 PM JST
**Venue:** Keio University Mita Campus, East Building 8F Hall
**Capacity:** 120 people (in-person); livestream and video archive available
**Admission:** Free
**Languages:** Japanese & English (simultaneous interpretation)

## Key Speakers
- **Audrey Tang** (former Taiwanese Digital Minister)
- **Glen Weyl** (economist, co-author of Plurality book)

## Shutaro Aoyama (é’å±±æŸŠå¤ªæœ— / blu3mo) Roles

Shutaro Aoyama appears in two sessions:

1. **Session 2 Moderator** (3:05â€“3:45 PM): "New Forms of Consensus Using Collective Intelligence" â€“ moderating discussion with Colin Megill, Hirokazu Nishio, and tonfi Yuki

2. **Session 5 Panelist** (5:20â€“6:00 PM): "Will AI Advance Democracy?" â€“ appearing alongside Colin Megill, Audrey Tang, and Takahiro Anno, with Akinori Oyama moderating

## Additional Notable Panelists/Moderators
Sessions feature academics (Keigo Komamura, Shigeki Uno, Yosuke Yasuda), policy experts, technologists, and civil society leaders addressing topics including Polis, Community Notes, Quadratic Funding/Voting, and AI's role in democratic systems.

# é’å±± Project Details

**Participant Name:** é’å±± æŸŠå¤ªæœ— (Shotaro Aoyama)

**Institution:** ãã‚“ã¾å›½éš›ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸãƒ¼ é«˜ç­‰éƒ¨ (Gunma International Academy, Upper Secondary Division)

**Project Manager:** ç¨²è¦‹ æ˜Œå½¦ (Masahiko Inami), Professor at Tokyo University's Institute of Advanced Science and Technology

**Funding Amount:** Â¥1,520,000

**Project Title:** "æ™‚é–“ã‚’æ“ä½œã™ã‚‹æ˜ åƒå‹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®é–‹ç™º" (Development of Time-Manipulating Video-Based Notebook)

**Project Overview:**

The initiative centers on developing a system linking classroom lecture recordings with handwritten notes. The core innovation enables students to control video playback speed during synchronous lessons, bridging asynchronous and real-time instruction benefits. The system processes "video content to naturally absorb timing discrepancies" arising from learner-controlled playback adjustments.

**Selection Rationale:**

The proposal demonstrates "ambitious efforts to adapt to both synchronous and asynchronous lectures using VR and omnidirectional imaging technology." Evaluators noted its timely applicability to "remote lectures currently conducted in various settings."

Based on the search results, here's what I found about blu3mo, broad listening, and Talk to the City:

## Overview

Broad listening (ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒªã‚¹ãƒ‹ãƒ³ã‚°) is an effort to widely collect and visualize diverse citizen voices and use them for decision-making, using an open-source AI analysis tool called "Talk to the City" (TTTC).

## Connection to Talk to the City

Talk to the City was originally developed by AI Objective Institute, an NPO based in California, and has been used in practice in Taiwan and around the world. In March 2025, the Digital Democracy 2030 Project released "åºƒè´AI" (Kouchou AI) as open source, which is an improved version of Talk to the City adapted for Japanese local governments and politicians.

## How It Works

Broad listening collects and aggregates multiple voices to create a digest/summary, while broadcasting is the oppositeâ€”it copies one voice and spreads it to many people. SNS, Google Forms, surveys, and in-person interviews are used as diverse information sources, with AI analyzing and classifying the opinions.

## Connection to blu3mo

The search results mention that the concept is associated with "Plurality" advocated by Taiwan's digital minister Audrey Tang, and in Japan, AI engineer Takahiro Anno's team (who ran in the 2024 Tokyo gubernatorial election) has introduced and promoted this approach. However, the specific connection to "blu3mo" is not clearly detailed in these results.

content.text:
Now I have comprehensive information. Let me compile all findings.

Here is a summary of the research findings on **Aoyama Shutaro** (also known online as **Bluemo / blu3mo**):

---

## 1. Academic Background at Columbia University

Shutaro Aoyama is studying **Computer Science and Philosophy** at Columbia University's School of Engineering, pursuing a **Bachelor of Science degree**. He was selected as an **Egleston Scholar**, which is awarded to the top 1% of Columbia Engineering students.

At Columbia, he works as an **Undergraduate Researcher in the CGUI Lab** (Computer Graphics and User Interfaces Lab), led by Professor Steven Feiner. His research focuses on **Computer-mediated Reality (XR)** and **AI-mediated Communication**.

Before Columbia, he attended **Gunma International Academy** (a high school in Japan) and was from **Kumagaya, Saitama Prefecture**. He was also a recipient of the **Masayoshi Son Foundation Scholarship** (1st period).

In 2020, while still in high school, he was accepted into the **IPA Mitou (æœªè¸) IT Talent Discovery and Development Program** with a project titled "Development of a Time-Manipulating Video-Based Notebook" (æ™‚é–“ã‚’æ“ä½œã™ã‚‹æ˜ åƒå‹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®é–‹ç™º), under PM Masahiko Inami of the University of Tokyo, with funding of 1,520,000 yen. This project linked classroom lecture recordings with handwritten notes, allowing students to control video playback speed during synchronous lessons.

**Sources:**
- [Columbia Engineering Egleston Scholars - Shutaro Aoyama](https://www.engineering.columbia.edu/egleston-scholars/shutaro-aoyama)
- [IPA Mitou 2020 Project Overview (Aoyama PJ)](https://www.ipa.go.jp/jinzai/mitou/it/2020/gaiyou_in-1.html)

---

## 2. IEEE VR 2024 Paper

His IEEE VR 2024 paper is **not** titled "Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication." That is a separate, later paper. At IEEE VR 2024, he presented:

**"Asynchronously Assigning, Monitoring, and Managing Assembly Goals in Virtual Reality for High-Level Robot Teleoperation"**
- Published at: **IEEE VR 2024** (IEEE Conference on Virtual Reality and 3D User Interfaces)
- Co-authors: Jen-Shuo Liu, Portia Wang, Shreeya Jain, Xuezhen Wang, Jingxi Xu, Shuran Song, Barbara Tversky, Steven Feiner
- IEEE Xplore DOI reference: [10.1109/VR58804.2024.00040](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/10494163/)
- This paper presented a VR user interface for robot teleoperation supporting high-level specification of 3D object positions and orientations in remote assembly tasks.

An earlier version of this work was published at **SUI 2023** (Symposium on Spatial User Interaction):
- **"Built to Order: A Virtual Reality Interface for Assigning High-Level Assembly Goals to Remote Robots"** (2023)

The **"Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication"** paper (arXiv:2502.18201, February 2025) is a separate, more recent work:
- Full title: "Intersubjective Model of AI-mediated Communication: Augmenting Human-Human Text Chat through LLM-based Adaptive Agent Pair"
- Co-authors: Rintaro Chujo, Ari Hautasaari, Takeshi Naemura
- This paper proposes a novel communication framework where individuals engage in conversations with AI agents within independent chat environments, and communication between humans occurs indirectly through information sharing between these AI agents.

He also published at **UIST 2022**:
- **"Shadow Play using Ultrasound Levitated Props"** (co-author: Kei Asano)

**Sources:**
- [arXiv: Intersubjective Model paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.18201)
- [IEEE Xplore: VR 2024 paper](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/10494163/)
- [DBLP: Shutaro Aoyama publications](https://dblp.org/pid/332/1395.html)

---

## 3. Involvement with Sony CSL's Cybernetic Humanity Team

Shutaro Aoyama worked as a **Research Assistant at Sony Computer Science Laboratories (Sony CSL)** and at the **Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST)**. According to ZoomInfo and LinkedIn, his email domain was `@sonycsl.co.jp`, confirming his affiliation.

Sony CSL's **Cybernetic Humanity** research is led by **Dr. Shunichi Kasahara**, who runs the **Cybernetic Humanity Studio** -- a collaboration between Sony CSL and OIST. This research field explores the "new humanity" emerging from the integration of humans and computers, focusing on augmented sensation/perception, extended cognition and the "self," and social self formed through interaction.

He also collaborated with the **Naemura Lab at the University of Tokyo** (Professor Takeshi Naemura, who is a co-author on the Intersubjective Model paper).

**Sources:**
- [Sony CSL Cybernetic Humanity](https://www.sonycsl.co.jp/en/worldviews/cybernetic-humanity/)
- [Shunichi Kasahara - Cybernetic Humanity](https://shunichikasahara.com/)
- [LinkedIn: Shutaro Aoyama - Sony CSL](https://www.linkedin.com/in/shutaro-aoyama-11a387176/)
- [ZoomInfo: Shutaro Aoyama at Sony CSL](https://www.zoominfo.com/p/Shutaro-Aoyama/9344557456)

---

## 4. Role in the 2024 Tokyo Gubernatorial Election with Team Anno

Aoyama was part of **Team Anno (ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ å®‰é‡)**, the volunteer/engineer group that supported **Takahiro Anno (å®‰é‡è²´åš)** during the **2024 Tokyo gubernatorial election** (July 7, 2024). Anno finished 5th with approximately 154,638 votes.

According to the book manuscript in this repository (file `/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/11_03_å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ.md`), Aoyama was involved in the **Digital Democracy 2030 (DD2030)** and **Team Mirai** activities, and developed tools like **"Idobata" (ã„ã©ã°ãŸ)** -- an online dialogue/deliberation tool used in the political campaigns.

Additionally, in the file `/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/09_03_ã‚µã‚¤ãƒœã‚¦ã‚º.md`, Aoyama is mentioned as a developer who helped set up a dedicated broad listening environment for **Cybozu** (a Japanese tech company).

His specific role in Team Anno appears to have been on the **technical/engineering side**, working on digital democracy tools and broad listening systems used during the campaign.

**Sources:**
- [Team Mirai - Wikipedia](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%83%81%E3%83%BC%E3%83%A0%E3%81%BF%E3%82%89%E3%81%84)
- [2024 Tokyo Gubernatorial Election - Wikipedia](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024%E5%B9%B4%E6%9D%B1%E4%BA%AC%E9%83%BD%E7%9F%A5%E4%BA%8B%E9%81%B8%E6%8C%99)
- Book manuscript: `/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/11_03_å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ.md`

---

## 5. Role in the 2025 å‚é™¢é¸ with Team Mirai

**Team Mirai (ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ã¿ã‚‰ã„)** was formally established as a political party on **May 8, 2025**, evolving from the volunteer group that formed around Anno during the gubernatorial election. In the **2025 House of Councillors election** (July 20, 2025), Team Mirai won **1 seat** (party leader Anno Takahiro in proportional representation) and met the threshold for official political party status (over 2% of votes).

Aoyama's specific role in the 2025 å‚é™¢é¸ campaign is not explicitly documented in public search results. However, his X (Twitter) account (@blu3mo) shows he posted about achieving the "early voting" goal on the **Team Mirai Action Board** on July 14, 2025, indicating active participation/support. His broader involvement is in the **technical infrastructure and digital democracy tools** that underpin Team Mirai's approach.

According to the book manuscript (`11_03_å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ.md`), Aoyama co-founded **Plural Reality LLC (åˆåŒä¼šç¤¾ å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ)** with Takagi Shunsuke, which implements broad listening knowledge in practice. The manuscript states he came through "DD2030 and Team Mirai activities" to develop these tools.

**Sources:**
- [Team Mirai Official Website](https://team-mir.ai/)
- [Jiji: Team Mirai meets party requirements](https://www.jiji.com/jc/article?k=2025072100143&g=pol)
- [Nikkei: Anno wins proportional seat](https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOUA2042K0Q5A720C2000000/)
- [blu3mo on X re: Team Mirai Action Board](https://x.com/blu3mo/status/1944965769395363871)

---

## 6. Plurality Tokyo Appearances

Aoyama participated in the **Plurality Tokyo Namerakaigi #2** event on **May 10, 2025**, held at Keio University Mita Campus to celebrate the Japanese publication of the **"Plurality" book** by Audrey Tang and Glen Weyl. He had two roles:

1. **Session 2 Moderator** (3:05-3:45 PM): "New Forms of Consensus Using Collective Intelligence" (Polis -- é›†åˆçŸ¥ã‚’ä½¿ã£ãŸåˆæ„ã®æ–°ãŸãªã‹ãŸã¡) -- moderating discussion with **Colin Megill**, **Hirokazu Nishio**, and **tonfi Yuki**.

2. **Session 5 Panelist** (5:20-6:00 PM): "Will AI Advance Democracy?" (AIã¯æ°‘ä¸»ä¸»ç¾©ã‚’é€²åŒ–ã•ã›ã‚‹ã‹ï¼Ÿ) -- appearing alongside **Colin Megill**, **Audrey Tang**, and **Takahiro Anno**, with Akinori Oyama moderating.

**Sources:**
- [Plurality Tokyo Namerakaigi #2 Event Page (Luma)](https://lu.ma/ienn4p0k)
- [Plurality Tokyo Official Site](https://plurality.tokyo/)
- [Keio X-Dignity Center Event Announcement](https://www.x-dignity.kgri.keio.ac.jp/news/848/)

---

## Additional Context from the Book Repository

In this book's codebase, Aoyama is referenced as:
- **Co-founder of Plural Reality LLC (åˆåŒä¼šç¤¾ å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ)** with Takagi Shunsuke (`/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/11_03_å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ.md`)
- **Developer** who set up Cybozu's dedicated broad listening environment (`/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/09_03_ã‚µã‚¤ãƒœã‚¦ã‚º.md`)
- **Author** expected to write Chapter 10 on overseas broad listening (`/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/10_æµ·å¤–ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒªã‚¹ãƒ‹ãƒ³ã‚°ï¼ˆTTTCï¼‰ã®åˆ©ç”¨.md` -- currently just has "é’å±±ãŒæ›¸ã")

Aoyama was part of **Team Anno (ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ å®‰é‡)**, the volunteer/engineer group that supported **Takahiro Anno (å®‰é‡è²´åš)** during the **2024 Tokyo gubernatorial election** (July 7, 2024). Anno finished 5th with approximately 154,638 votes.

According to the book manuscript in this repository (file `/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/11_03_å¤šå…ƒç¾å®Ÿ.md`), Aoyama was involved in the **Digital Democracy 2030 (DD2030)** and **Team Mirai** activities, and developed tools like **"Idobata" (ã„ã©ã°ãŸ)** -- an online dialogue/deliberation tool used in the political campaigns.

Additionally, in the file `/Users/tkgshn/Developer/plural-reality/broad-listening-book/09_03_ã‚µã‚¤ãƒœã‚¦ã‚º.md`, Aoyama is mentioned as a developer who helped set up a dedicated broad listening environment for **Cybozu** (a Japanese tech company).

His specific role in Team Anno appears to have been on the **technical/engineering side**, working on digital democracy tools and broad listening systems used during the campaign.

## 5. Role in the 2025 å‚é™¢é¸ with Team Mirai

**Team Mirai (ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ã¿ã‚‰ã„)** was formally established as a political party on **May 8, 2025**, evolving from the volunteer group that formed around Anno during the gubernatorial election. In the **2025 House of Councillors election** (July 20, 2025), Team Mirai won **1 seat** (party leader Anno Takahiro in proportional representation) and met the threshold for official political party status (over 2% of votes).

Aoyama's specific role in the 2025 å‚é™¢é¸ campaign is not explicitly documented in public search results. ## 6. Plurality Tokyo Appearances

Aoyama participated in the **Plurality Tokyo Namerakaigi #2** event on **May 10, 2025**, held at Keio University Mita Campus to celebrate the Japanese publication of the **"Plurality" book** by Audrey Tang and Glen Weyl. He had two roles:

    print(f\"Error: {e}\")
    print(sys.stdin.read()[:200])
"'

## AIæ™‚ä»£ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³

Now I have a much clearer picture. Let me analyze what I have:

1. **Current chapter 10 on main**: Just a placeholder with "é’å±±ãŒæ›¸ã"
2. **chapter-10-rough-draft branch**: Has a detailed draft with:
   - 10.1 Introduction
   - 10.2 Taiwan vTaiwan (nishio's part)
   - 10.3 Israel-Palestine (tokoroten's part)
   - 10.4 Common principles
   - 10.5 Recursive sensemaking (started)
3. **Column "AIæ™‚ä»£ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³"**: Has the Jigsaw/Bowling Green content


4. **The task**: I need to add the Jigsaw/Bowling Green section as part 3, but there's a numbering conflict since 10.3 is already assigned to Israel-Palestine in the rough draft. The meeting notes indicate taka handles part 3, so I need to figure out whether this should replace 10.3 or be inserted as a new section that shifts the existing numbering.

Looking at the Scrapbox TODO more carefully, I see the real work is taking the existing column content about Jigsaw and Sensemaker that was already merged in PR #34, then restructuring it to fit the chapter 10 context while drawing a comparison with chapter 3 to show where Japan stands versus how far other countries have progressed.

The rough draft already has Taiwan and Israel-Palestine as sections 10.2 and 10.3, so I need to create a new section for the Jigsaw and Bowling Green casesâ€”likely 10.4â€”that integrates taka's column content while maintaining that domestic-versus-international contrast.

Based on the web search results, I found information about the Jigsaw Facilitation in the AI Era report. Here are the key opportunity areas identified:

The report identifies five main opportunity areas: Scaled Access, Dynamic Learning, Live Sensemaking, Futurecasting, and Sensemaking For The People.

More specifically, these areas include multilingual communications and tailored outreach; multimodal tools for evidence discovery; real-time conversation analysis and visualization; scenario planning and extrapolation; and interactive public-facing analysis and reporting.

The report originated from an ethnographic research study in Spring 2025 led by Ian Beacock and Emily Saltz at Jigsaw, a technology incubator within Google, and 22 facilitators representing a range of geographies, organizations, and traditions participated.

It's important to note that these opportunity areas and accompanying design visualizations are not products that Jigsaw is actively working on or necessarily planning to create, but rather are "offered as potential inspiration for others to build on."

Meet Googleâ€™s Civic Tech Experiment.","url":"https://www.adweek.com/media/not-all-ai-is-for-profit-meet-googles-civic-tech-experiment/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Jigsaw's Sensemaker, Polis, and civic engagement:

## Overview

Sensemaker is an evolving toolkit developed by Jigsaw that is designed to help make sense of large-scale conversations, empowering users to categorize, summarize, and identify areas of agreement and disagreement in any discussion.

## Technology & Capabilities

The Sensemaking tools leverage Google's Gemini models to categorize and summarize large-scale input into clear insights while retaining nuance. The library offers a transparent look into Jigsaw's methods for categorization, summarization, and identifying agreement/disagreement in complex text.

## Integration with Polis

The initiative leveraged Jigsaw's open-source tool Sensemaker and Polis, an open source real-time tool for gathering public input. Polis has faced a bottleneck in reporting, as conversations are labor-intensive to moderate effectively, and human facilitators dedicate countless hours to distilling Polis results into reports that are accessible to both participants and decision-makers.

## Real-World Application: Bowling Green, Kentucky

Nearly 8,000 residents in a county of roughly 130,000 participated in a month-long online conversation about their community's future, with community members weighing in over one million times, creating one of the largest online civic conversations ever held in the United States. The tool saved hundreds of hours of manual analysis and gave the planning team more time to analyze the results and make the best recommendations for the county's future.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the BG 2050 initiative in Bowling Green, Kentucky and its use of Polis and SenseMaker for civic engagement:

## BG 2050 Project Overview

Bowling Green is projected to double in size by 2050, and community leaders are working to ensure the city is prepared for this growth. "What Could BG Be?" grew out of the BG 2050 Project, an initiative led by Innovation Engine on behalf of the Warren County government to develop a 25-year vision to guide the anticipated rapid future growth of the region.

## Technology and Civic Engagement Platform

Residents submitted their input through a newly launched project website, where an open-ended prompt â€” powered by the interactive tech platform Polis â€” invited them to share what they hoped to see in their community over the next 25 years. Bowling Green and Warren County officials used SenseMaker, developed by Jigsaw, to digest and categorize large volumes of resident feedback and create a shared community vision for the next 25 years.

## Participation Results

The initiative achieved remarkable engagement: In just 33 days, 7,890 residents weighed in over one million times on the future of Warren County. The AI pilot boosted community input nearly 80-fold, Jigsaw said Tuesday in a Medium post.

## Key Findings

Over half (2,370) had an agreement rate of over 80 percent. The report revealed major priorities for the community included not only commonplace issues like better managing roads and traffic â€” a prime concern in Bowling Green as in any other fast-growing city â€” but also a focus on new nightlife and entertainment options, increasing art and cultural festivals, preserving and expanding parks and greenspaces, and fostering a greater sense of community pride.

## Community Impact

The feedback from the public painted a clear picture of a community both more civically engaged and connected across differences after What Could BG Be?. After participating, people reported that they: Felt more confident that their voice matters on important issues that affect Bowling Green (70%)

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Bowling Green 2050 strategic plan, citizen participation, and the Polis platform:

## Overview

The "What Could BG Be?" initiative feeds into a larger project expected to influence decision-making over the next 25 years: BG 2050. Bowling Green is projected to double in size by 2050, and community leaders are working to ensure the city is prepared for this growth.

## The Polis Platform

Polis is an open-source, machine-learning system for gathering, analyzing, and understanding what large groups of people think in their own words. The Computational Democracy Project utilizes a technology called Polis to solicit and analyze data through whatcouldbgbe.com, which is akin to a community-wide online conversation.

## Participation Results

The ongoing outreach campaign has engaged more than 4,700 participants, with about 5,500 statements submitted (nearly 3,500 after being moderated primarily for redundancy) and more than 500,000 votes cast, according to Friday data. One of its founding members notes that "What Could BG Be?" is one of the most engaged with initiatives in Polis' history.

## Key Findings

The outcomes and priorities of the roadmap will be determined by the 'What Could BG Be' pilot, which proved that people agree on the vision more often than they disagree, with a high proportion of statements having 80% or more agreement. Residents from both ends of the political spectrum concurred on the need for better mental health resources and sustainable development.

## AI Analysis

The campaign has partnered with the Computational Democracy Project and Google's Jigsaw to analyze the community feedback using AI and data tools. A report summarizing the community's input was published in April and will help shape the broader BG 2050 strategic planning effort.

content.content:
# What Could BG Be? Project Summary

## Project Overview
"What Could BG Be?" was a month-long online initiative hosted by the BG 2050 Project, a long-term strategic planning effort for Warren County's future.

## Participation Numbers
- **7,890** local residents participated
- **3,940** unique ideas submitted
- **1,034,868** total weighted votes cast
- **33-day** duration

## Timeline & Rationale
Warren County is projected to nearly double in size over the next 25 years, prompting proactive planning through 2050. The initiative aims to deliver a vision document charting the course from present to 2050.

## Eight Community Pillars
Storytelling, Quality of Life, Tourism, Economic Development, Talent Development, Public Health, Housing, and Infrastructure

## Technology Platform
**Polis** was the engagement platformâ€”an open-source, machine-learning system developed by the Computational Democracy Project that gathers and analyzes large-scale public conversations through sentiment analysis and clustering.

## Key Partners
- **Innovation Engine** (Bowling Green strategy firm, creative direction)
- **The Computational Democracy Project** (Polis platform developer)
- **Jigsaw** (Google's unit providing sensemaking tools)
- **"The Creative Dept."** (local pop-up agency): VidMonster Productions, Oliver Creative, Forerunner, Hillary Rickel, Madison Whittle, CrowdSouth, BBG Events, and Lunae

## Goals
Enable residents to imagine and collaboratively shape Warren County's collective future through inclusive, data-driven planning.

content.content:
# BG 2050 Initiative: Bowling Green's AI-Powered Civic Engagement

## Overview
Warren County, Kentucky launched an ambitious community survey called BG 2050 to gather input on the county's future as Bowling Green faced expected population doubling over 25 years.

## Participation Numbers
- **Nearly 8,000 residents** participated over 33 days
- Approximately **10% of Bowling Green's population** (city has 76,000+ residents)
- **Over 1 million votes** cast on various proposals

## Technology & Partners
**Jigsaw** (Google's tech incubator) developed **Sensemaker**, an AI tool that:
- Analyzed vast quantities of information quickly
- Synthesized and categorized survey results
- Shared findings with the public

Yasmin Green (Jigsaw CEO) described the mission: "figure out how to help us stay in the conversation together."

## Timeline
- **2017**: Judge Executive Doug Gorman learned Bowling Green would double in population within 25 years
- **Earlier this year** (2025): County launched marketing campaign and website

## Key Topics & Consensus
Residents voted on ideas including:
- More parks and schools
- Entertainment venues
- Affordable housing
- Public transit
- Transportation solutions

**Over half the proposals achieved 80% agreement**, demonstrating surprising community alignment despite political divisions.

## Notable Quotes

**Doug Gorman**: "what we just conducted was the largest town hall in America."

**Daniel Tarnagda**: "if you don't ask, you don't know...one of the best ways to bring people more together."

**Laura Torres**: Survey accessibility meant "you didn't have to physically be somewhere to have your voice heard."

## Planning Implementation
Judge Executive Gorman committed to implementing as many approved ideas as quickly as possible, with constituents monitoring progress.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about the Jigsaw Sensemaker report on Bowling Green, Kentucky:

## Project Overview

Bowling Green, Kentucky used Sensemaker, an LLM-based tool from Google's Jigsaw division, to analyze community feedback on the city's future. The "What Could BG Be?" digital conversation invited local residents to submit ideas and vote on other submissions over a month-long period.

## Community Participation

Over 7,700 residents participated, sharing 3,940 unique ideas and over one million opinions during the one-month timeframe.

## Key Findings and Consensus Statements

The report revealed major priorities for the community included better managing roads and traffic, a focus on new nightlife and entertainment options, increasing art and cultural festivals, preserving and expanding parks and greenspaces, and fostering a greater sense of community pride.

Over half (2,370) of the ideas submitted had an agreement rate of over 80 percent.

Additionally, the AI uncovered surprising consensus across political divides on topics like parks, housing, and mental health, with widespread agreement on improving public parks and addressing housing affordability. Residents from both ends of the political spectrum concurred on the need for better mental health resources and sustainable development.

## How Sensemaker Worked

Sensemaker categorized the ideas submitted into topics and subtopics and summarized the overall findings into a report, completing this analysis in a matter of minutes as opposed to days â€” or even weeks.

Based on the search results, here's what the "What Could BG Be" report contains:

## Report Overview

Public input was sourced on WhatCouldBGBe.com via Polis between February 14 and March 17, 2025 to inform the BG 2050 Project. The report was produced by Innovation Engine, a Bowling Green-based strategy firm, and made possible by Jigsaw's open-source Sensemaker.

## Methodology

Ideas submitted to the conversation were categorized by Jigsaw's Sensemaker, leveraging Gemini, Google's most advanced AI. No personal information was captured, and no demographic data was stored.

## Key Topics and Consensus

The report identified several major themes of community input:

- **Arts and Culture**: The conversation in Bowling Green showed strong support for expanding arts and culture offerings, including new venues, festivals, and support for local artists, with statements calling for new museums and cultural centers focused on local history and other topics.

- **Transportation and Infrastructure**: Statements emphasized improving roads and traffic flow, expanding pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure, and exploring options for enhanced public transportation, including potential rail service, with the future of the Bowling Green airport and parking solutions also discussed.

- **Economic Development**: Statements prioritized diversifying the economy, supporting small businesses, revitalizing downtown, and expanding retail and tourism offerings, with workforce development, higher wages, and attracting and retaining talent also being key themes.

- **Community Values**: The conversation focused on balancing growth with preserving Bowling Green's character, celebrating its history and cultural heritage, and fostering a more inclusive and collaborative community.

content.content:
# What Could BG Be? - Complete Data Extraction

## Participation Metrics
- **Participants:** 7,890 local Warren County residents
- **Total Votes Cast:** 1,034,868
- **Timeline:** 33 days (February 14 - March 17, 2025)
- **Platform:** Polis

## Ideas Submitted by Category

| Category | Subcategories | Idea Count |
|----------|---------------|-----------|
| **Arts & Culture** | Entertainment Venues (330), Festivals (102), Visual Arts (75), Museums (74), Performing Arts (60), Other (3) | 644 |
| **Infrastructure & Transportation** | Roads & Traffic (209), Pedestrian/Bike (102), Public Transit (93), Parking (47), Airport (30), Other (93) | 574 |
| **Economic Development** | Business Diversification (189), Retail (166), Tourism (74), Workforce (70) | 499 |
| **Community Identity** | Community Pride (237), Collaboration (92), Sense of Place (69), Cultural Heritage (49), Southern Hospitality (32) | 479 |
| **Environment & Sustainability** | Parks/Green Spaces (124), Preservation (68), Recycling (55), Renewable Energy (38), Water Quality (29), Air Quality (11) | 325 |
| **Housing** | Affordability (100), Housing Variety (74), Zoning (52), Specific Populations (26), Homelessness (21), Infrastructure (10) | 283 |
| **Education** | K-12 (153), Higher Ed (41), Early Childhood (25), Adult Education (22), Alternative (13), Vocational (12), Special Ed (5), Other (1) | 272 |
| **Public Safety & Services** | Regulations (103), Crime & Policing (93), Public Services (83), Homelessness/Social Services (59), Emergency Services (31), Other (1) | 370 |
| **Food & Agriculture** | Restaurant Variety (77), Local Production (39), Food Access (38), Agricultural Support (18), Urban Gardens (16) | 188 |
| **Equity & Inclusion** | Community Pride (237), Immigrant/Refugee Integration (32), LGBTQ+ Support (21), Racial Equity (21), Accessibility (18), Economic Empowerment (18), Representation (8), Other (9) | 364 |
| **Healthcare** | Healthcare Facilities (35), Preventative Care (32), Healthcare Professionals (20), Specialized Services (17), Senior Care (12), Access (11), Substance Abuse (11), Mental Health (10), Public Health (5) | 153 |
| **Other** | International Relations (2) | 2 |

## High-Consensus Topics (Most Agreement)

Seven statements demonstrated strongest community consensus:
1. Family-friendly activities
2. County-wide development
3. Grocery stores
4. Connecting downtown to riverfront
5. Sidewalks & walkability
6. Alleviating traffic on Scottsville Road
7. Flooding & disaster preparedness

## Referenced Inspirations

Attractions mentioned as models included: City Museum (St. Louis), Crystal Bridges (Bentonville), Brightline Rail (Florida), Red Rocks Amphitheater (Colorado), The Gathering Place (Tulsa), and bike trail networks from multiple cities.

## Methodology

AI Categorization: "AI was used to categorize all ideas submitted to What Could BG Be?" utilizing "Gemini, Google's most advanced AI" through Jigsaw's open-source Sensemaker tool.

Key limitation noted: "While Jigsaw's Sensemaker utilizes cutting-edge technical approaches to minimize AI hallucinations, conclusions should be verified before use."

## Data Collection
- **No personal information captured**
- **No demographic data stored**
- Public dataset available for download

## Next Steps

Project volunteers will deliver policy recommendations to Warren County leadership in late 2025, incorporating this report to inform 25-year strategic planning through the BG 2050 Project.

# Bowling Green AI Civic Engagement Initiative: Key Details

## Project Name & Timeline
The article doesn't explicitly name the project "BG 2050," though it references a "25-year comprehensive plan." The initiative ran for **33 days** earlier in 2025.

## Participation Numbers
- **1 million+ votes** cast on over 4,000 ideas
- **2,370 points of consensus** identified
- Thousands engaged online

## Platform & Technology
**Polis** â€“ an open-source tool from the Computational Democracy Project using machine learning to cluster opinions and highlight overlaps, creating a "consensus map."

## Topics Addressed
- Infrastructure and education
- Public parks improvement
- Housing affordability
- Mental health resources
- Sustainable development
- Economic growth strategies
- Zoning reforms

## Consensus Findings
- **80%** of participants found common ground on economic growth strategies
- Residents across political spectrum agreed on mental health services and sustainable development
- The system revealed "surprising levels of agreement that transcended partisan lines"

## Key Quote
"We discovered we're more alike than we thought" â€“ participant statement

## Cost & Leadership
- Budget: **under $10,000**
- Mayor Todd Alcott involved in implementation

## Notable Result
The AI stripped away inflammatory language to reveal shared priorities that "might have been drowned out in heated debates."

content.content:
# Sensemaker Overview

## What It Is
Sensemaker is a toolkit developed by Jigsaw (a Google incubator) designed to help understand large-scale conversations. The tool leverages Google AI to transform discussions into actionable insights by processing massive volumes of participant input.

## Core Capabilities

**Categorization & Analysis:**
- Identifies key topics and themes from conversations
- Provides clear overviews of what mattered most to participants

**Summarization:**
- Breaks down topics into easy-to-read summaries
- Explores subtopics, key insights, and emerging themes
- Creates conversation digests for clarity

**Agreement/Disagreement Identification:**
- "Highlight where conversation participants agree and disagree, helping users understand different perspectives at a glance"

## How It Works
The page references a Medium article explaining the process but doesn't detail technical architecture on this page. Users can access more information through the "How it Works" link.

## Open Source Status
Sensemaker includes a **Developer Library** publicly available on GitHub (Jigsaw-Code/sensemaking-tools/), encouraging developers to review code and share feedback.

## Target Users
- Deliberative technology platforms
- Community leaders and managers
- Decision makers
- Conversation participants

## Polis Data Analysis
The webpage does not specifically mention Polis or capabilities for analyzing Polis data.

## Five Opportunity Areas

The report identifies five untapped, high-value opportunities for AI to support facilitators: by scaling access, offering dynamic learning, generating live synthesis and sensemaking, helping with futurecasting, and improving public sensemaking outputs.

## About the Report

Published by Jigsaw in October 2025, the report is based on a detailed study of 22 facilitators from around the world, representing many different backgrounds and traditions. 

It offers practical guidance for funders, facilitators, and technology developers on creating AI tools that can help people have better, more meaningful group conversations.

All opportunities should be explored in partnership with facilitators and publics, to build trust in the technology and ensure that it augments the transformational dialogue.

It's worth noting that these opportunity areas and accompanying design visualizations are not products that Jigsaw is actively working on or necessarily planning to create, but are offered as potential inspiration for others to build on.

The full report is available as a PDF from Google's Jigsaw division.

Links: [{"title":"BG 2050 findings revealed | Bowling Green Daily News","url":"https://bgdailynews.com/2025/04/15/news_bg2050-041625/"},{"title":"'What Could BG Be?' initiative set to idealize the future","url":"https://wkuherald.com/83096/news/what-could-bg-be-initiative-set-to-idealize-the-future/"},{"title":"Kentucky city wraps AI project collecting community planning feedback | StateScoop","url":"https://statescoop.com/bowling-green-kentucky-ai-community-planning/"},{"title":"County Line Fall 2025: Warren County dreams big","url":"https://mydigitalpublication.com/publication/?i=855080&article_id=5059262&view=articleBrowser"},{"title":"Workshop seeks participants to shape countyâ€™s future | Bowling Green Daily News","url":"https://bgdailynews.com/2024/06/04/workshop-seeks-participants-to-shape-countys-future/"},{"title":"'What Could BG Be\" inspires national polling initiative - The Advocate-Messenger","url":"https://amnews.com/2025/11/20/what-could-bg-be-inspires-national-polling-initiative/"},{"title":"'What Could BG Be\" inspires national polling initiative - Claiborne Progress","url":"https://claiborneprogress.net/2025/11/20/what-could-bg-be-inspires-national-polling-initiative/"},{"title":"Bowling Green, Ky., Used AI to Drive Public Engagement","url":"https://www.govtech.com/artificial-intelligence/bowling-green-ky-used-ai-to-drive-public-engagement"},{"title":"'What Could BG Be\" inspires national polling initiative - Harlan Enterprise","url":"https://harlanenterprise.net/2025/11/20/what-could-bg-be-inspires-national-polling-initiative/"},{"title":"How one of the fastest-growing cities in Kentucky used AI to plan for the next 25 years | by Jigsaw | Jigsaw | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/jigsaw/how-one-of-the-fastest-growing-cities-in-kentucky-used-ai-to-plan-for-the-next-25-years-3b70c4fd1412"}]

## What Could BG Be Initiative - Overview and Impact

The "What Could BG Be" feedback program was a community-wide initiative that ran from mid-February to mid-March, inviting members of the public to share their ideas for how Bowling Green and Warren County should change and grow over the next 25 years.

### Leadership and Organization

Warren County Judge-Executive Doug Gorman worked with Sam Ford and Amanda Havard, cofounders of Innovation Engine, on this initiative. The BG 2050 initiative was initiated by Warren County Judge/Executive Doug Gorman in 2023 during a summer workshop, but officially launched in summer 2024.

### Scope and Participation

Nearly 8,000 residents weighed in with some 4,000 ideas submitted and more than 1 million votes were cast. Warren County's massive, springtime polling initiative What Could BG Be became the largest U.S. town hall ever.

### Results and 80% Agreement Impact

Gorman was excited to see that 60% of the ideas had an agreement rate of more than 80%. Sensemaker was able to sort the What Could BG Be ideas into topics and dozens of subtopics, identify areas of alignment and approval, and create a summary of the overall findings.

### Implementation Impact

Insights gleaned from What Could BG Be and the BG 2050 Project have offered clarity on local priorities, and the Warren County Fiscal Court is already taking steps to implement some of those ideas. Just this summer, the county approved a $5 million investment to create a unified fire department, moving nine volunteer fire departments under one system.

content.content:
# "What Could BG Be" Inspires National Polling Initiative

## Overview
Bowling Green's springtime polling initiative "What Could BG Be" has inspired a national expansion called **We The People**, unveiled Monday by the Napolitan Institute in partnership with Google's Jigsaw division.

## The Local Model
The original Bowling Green town hall collected over 7,000 statements and garnered 1 million "agree" or "disagree" votes using AI-driven technology from Jigsaw to facilitate community dialogue about local issues.

## National Expansion
**We The People** scales the model nationally by:
- Surveying five participants in each of 435 congressional districts
- Asking citizens about their understanding of freedom and equality
- Using an AI chatbot to generate deeper responses (averaging 140 words versus the typical 8-word survey response)
- Categorizing responses into 26 "ideals" for broader agreement/disagreement

## Key Quotes
- Scott Rasmussen (Napolitan CEO): "At 140 words, you begin to hear people's thoughts and connections"
- Scott Carpenter (Jigsaw Managing Director): "It's basically, in some ways, Google Maps of conversation"
- Rep. Brett Guthrie: "Technology may expose coarseness, but we can also use it to bring closeness"

## Results Timeline
The first report launches within weeks, with continued rollouts through July 4, 2026 (U.S. 250th anniversary).

content.content:
# Bowling Green "What Could BG Be" AI Pilot Project Details

## Participation Numbers
- Nearly 8,000 residents participated via the website
- Over 1 million feedback points collected during February-March voting period
- Original planning phase involved ~100 community leaders across sectors

## Timeline
- Project initiated: Early 2023 by Warren County Judge Executive Doug Gorman
- Website launch: Early 2025
- Feedback collection period: One month spanning February-March 2025
- Results announcement: Tuesday, April 16, 2025

## AI Implementation
**Technology Used:** Google Jigsaw's Sensemaker AI tool
**Functions:**
- Classified and summarized resident responses
- Generated interactive web report in minutes (vs. days/weeks manually)
- Ranked ideas by agreement, disagreement, or mixed opinion
- Processed 8 topics: housing, education, economic development, etc.

## Key Topics & Consensus
Eight pillar areas included healthcare access, education, and economic development. High-agreement themes:
- Bringing healthcare specialists to reduce Nashville travel
- Preserving historic buildings
- Prioritizing existing retail spaces over new construction
- "High proportion of statements had 80% or more agreement"

## Leadership Quotes
Judge Executive Doug Gorman: "gained so much valuable data from the general public" and the project "blown up so much bigger than I ever imagined."

Innovation Engine co-founder Sam Ford: "AI provides ability to save time and handle bigger scale...find patterns hard for human eye to detect."

## Implementation Partners
- Google Jigsaw (AI technology)
- Innovation Engine (local innovation firm)
- Polis platform (voting capability)

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about Jigsaw's work on facilitation in the AI era. Here's what the search revealed:

## Jigsaw's Facilitation AI Tools and Approaches

Jigsaw is an incubator within Google that builds technologies to give people greater agency in the world around them.

The search results show that Jigsaw has developed several AI-enabled tools specifically designed for facilitators working with large-scale conversations:

### Key Capabilities

Jigsaw offers multilingual, multimodal tools for tailored recruitment and improved participation, including translation features for language and cultural context, and multimodal features that allow public contributions in different formats like audio, video, and text.

Real-time conversation analysis and visualization tools for live sensemaking enable facilitators to quickly understand evolving conversations, provided the tools can be trained on specific conversation nuances and participants have chances to review or challenge AI summaries.

Jigsaw offers scenario planning and tradeoff extrapolation tools for futurecasting.

The platform includes multimodal education and evidence features for dynamic learning.

### Real-World Impact

Using Sensemaker, local leaders and community members quickly gained clearer, data-driven understanding of conversationsâ€”uncovering actionable insights in real-time, with the use of AI saving local leaders hundreds of hours sifting through public input.

The research notes that facilitators value these tools for their ability to enable real-time interaction with feedback data at scale, which wasn't previously possible.

Opinions abound | Bowling Green Daily News","url":"https://bgdailynews.com/2025/04/20/news_bg2050-042025/"},{"title":"BG 2050: Community input sought to shape next 25 years | Bowling Green Daily News","url":"https://bgdailynews.com/2025/02/17/bg-2050-community-input-sought-to-shape-next-25-years/"},{"title":"'What Could BG Be?' initiative set to idealize the future","url":"https://wkuherald.com/83096/news/what-could-bg-be-initiative-set-to-idealize-the-future/"},{"title":"About Sam â€“ Sam Ford","url":"https://samford.wordpress.com/about-sam/"},{"title":"Sam Ford | MIT Comparative Media Studies/Writing","url":"https://cmsw.mit.edu/profile/sam-ford/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about "What Could BG Be":

## Overview

"What Could BG Be?" is an initiative managed by Innovation Engine where users can anonymously submit responses and agree, disagree or pass on responses from other users on the website whatcouldbgbe.com. The goal is to gather information about what Bowling Green may look like in 2050.

## The Innovation Engine Team

Sam Ford and Amanda Havard are cofounders of Innovation Engine. Innovation Engine is a Bowling Green-based strategy firm that helps organizations unlock new value and drive growth through innovation, typically helping organizations do something they've never done before, or do something the way they've never done it before.

## Marketing Campaign

The campaign came together in a highly collaborative local effort with VidMonster Productions, Oliver Creative, Forerunner, Innovation Engine, Hillary Rickel, and Madison Whittle along with a host of guest contributors.

## Community Engagement

The heart of this campaign is about trying to go to where people already gather, according to Amanda Havard. The Warren County Public Library has been especially involved in the outreach, sharing information about the campaign across all library locations and its outreach initiatives such as the Little Free Shuttle and Feed and Read mobile library.

## Results

A launch event for the release of a public report that summarizes and highlights of the What Could BG Be? initiative occurred on Tuesday, April 15, 2025.

content.content:
# BG 2050 Findings Summary

## Participation Numbers
- **3,940 unique ideas** submitted from residents
- **Over 1 million votes** ("agree" or "disagree") cast on ideas

## Top Topic Categories
1. **Arts and Culture** - 644 ideas
2. **Infrastructure and Transportation** - 574 ideas
3. **Community Identity** - 479 ideas

## Key Context
The "What Could BG Be?" initiative ran from mid-February through mid-March 2025, asking residents to envision growth over the next 25 years. Warren County is projected to reach 200,000+ residents by 2050.

## Notable Quotes

Judge-Executive Doug Gorman stated: "Are we going to solve every problem, no. But if we don't make a plan for 2050, it will go to us and it will change."

Sam Ford (Innovation Engine cofounder) emphasized: "Do we want this to happen to us, or for us. If we want it to happen for us, we have to have a plan."

## Implementation Partners
- Innovation Engine (strategy firm)
- Warren County government
- Computational Democracy Project (nonprofit)
- 100+ community leaders
- Jigsaw (Google division)

## Student Input
Bowling Green Independent School District students contributed letters; Class of 2025 highlighted the desire for "a place where I can live and work and raise my family."

Results available at: **whatcouldbgbe.com**

A time capsule was buried April 15, 2025, to be opened in 25 years.

content.text:
Now I have comprehensive data from all the key sources. Let me compile the complete findings.

---

## Comprehensive Research Findings: BG 2050 / "What Could BG Be?" and Jigsaw's Facilitation Work

---

### 1. PROJECT OVERVIEW: BG 2050 and "What Could BG Be?"

BG 2050 is a 25-year strategic planning initiative for Warren County and Bowling Green, Kentucky. The project was initiated in 2023 by Warren County Judge-Executive **Doug Gorman**, who learned in 2017 that Bowling Green was projected to nearly double in population by 2050 (from roughly 130,000 to 200,000+ residents). "What Could BG Be?" was the public engagement component of BG 2050, designed to gather large-scale community input on the region's future.

The initiative was managed by **Innovation Engine**, a Bowling Green-based strategy firm co-founded by **Sam Ford** and **Amanda Havard**. Key technology partners included **The Computational Democracy Project** (which developed Polis), and **Jigsaw** (Google's technology incubator, which provided the Sensemaker AI analysis tool).

A local volunteer creative team called **"The Creative Dept."** handled branding and outreach, including VidMonster Productions, Oliver Creative, Forerunner, and others.

---

### 2. PARTICIPATION NUMBERS

- **7,890 local residents** participated (approximately 10% of Bowling Green's population of 76,000+, and roughly 6% of Warren County)
- **3,940 unique ideas/statements** were submitted
- **1,034,868 total weighted votes** were cast (agree/disagree/pass)
- The initiative ran for **33 days** (February 14 to March 17, 2025)
- One of the founding members of the Computational Democracy Project noted that "What Could BG Be?" was **one of the most engaged-with initiatives in Polis' history**
- Doug Gorman called it **"the largest town hall in America"**

For comparison, the original planning phase (starting in summer 2023/2024) had involved approximately 100 community leaders across sectors before the public-facing Polis conversation launched.

---

### 3. TIMELINE

| Date | Event |
|---|---|
| 2017 | Doug Gorman learns Bowling Green will double in population by 2050 |
| Summer 2023 | Gorman initiates BG 2050 planning with summer workshop |
| Summer 2024 | BG 2050 officially launches |
| February 14, 2025 | "What Could BG Be?" website goes live on whatcouldbgbe.com via Polis |
| March 17, 2025 | Voting period closes (33 days total) |
| April 15, 2025 | Public report released; launch event held; time capsule buried (to be opened in 25 years) |
| Late 2025 | Project volunteers deliver policy recommendations to Warren County leadership |
| Summer 2025 | Warren County Fiscal Court begins implementing ideas (e.g., $5 million unified fire department) |
| November 2025 | "We The People" national initiative announced, inspired by BG model |

---

### 4. HOW POLIS WAS USED

Polis is an open-source, machine-learning platform developed by the Computational Democracy Project. In this initiative:

- Residents visited **whatcouldbgbe.com** and responded to an open-ended prompt about what they hoped to see in their community over the next 25 years
- Participants could **submit their own ideas** as statements
- Participants could **vote agree, disagree, or pass** on statements from other residents
- Polis used machine learning to perform **sentiment analysis and clustering**, grouping participants by opinion patterns and creating a "consensus map"
- **No personal information** was captured and **no demographic data** was stored
- The complete dataset was made publicly available for download

---

### 5. HOW JIGSAW'S SENSEMAKER WAS USED TO ANALYZE THE DATA

Sensemaker is an open-source toolkit developed by Jigsaw (Google's technology incubator) that leverages **Google's Gemini AI model** to process large-scale conversation data. In the BG 2050 project, Sensemaker:

- **Categorized** all 3,940 submitted ideas into topics and dozens of subtopics
- **Summarized** overall findings into a comprehensive, accessible report
- **Identified areas of alignment and disagreement**, ranking ideas by agreement rate, disagreement, or mixed opinion
- Completed analysis that would have taken **days or weeks manually** in a matter of **minutes**
- Generated an **interactive web report** (published at polygraph-cool.github.io/m2-report/)
- Saved local leaders **hundreds of hours** of manual analysis work

The report includes an important caveat: "While Jigsaw's Sensemaker utilizes cutting-edge technical approaches to minimize AI hallucinations, conclusions should be verified before use."

Key technical note: Sensemaker's core capabilities include categorization and theme identification, summarization with subtopic exploration, and agreement/disagreement highlighting. Its developer library is open-source on GitHub (Jigsaw-Code/sensemaking-tools).

---

### 6. TOPICS THAT EMERGED (by idea count)

The Sensemaker categorized ideas into the following major topic areas:

| Category | Idea Count | Key Subtopics |
|---|---|---|
| **Arts & Culture** | 644 | Entertainment Venues (330), Festivals (102), Visual Arts (75), Museums (74), Performing Arts (60) |
| **Infrastructure & Transportation** | 574 | Roads & Traffic (209), Pedestrian/Bike (102), Public Transit (93), Parking (47), Airport (30) |
| **Economic Development** | 499 | Business Diversification (189), Retail (166), Tourism (74), Workforce (70) |
| **Community Identity** | 479 | Community Pride (237), Collaboration (92), Sense of Place (69), Cultural Heritage (49) |
| **Public Safety & Services** | 370 | Regulations (103), Crime & Policing (93), Public Services (83), Homelessness/Social Services (59) |
| **Equity & Inclusion** | 364 | Immigrant/Refugee Integration (32), LGBTQ+ Support (21), Racial Equity (21), Accessibility (18) |
| **Environment & Sustainability** | 325 | Parks/Green Spaces (124), Preservation (68), Recycling (55), Renewable Energy (38) |
| **Housing** | 283 | Affordability (100), Housing Variety (74), Zoning (52) |
| **Education** | 272 | K-12 (153), Higher Ed (41), Early Childhood (25), Adult Education (22) |
| **Food & Agriculture** | 188 | Restaurant Variety (77), Local Production (39), Food Access (38) |
| **Healthcare** | 153 | Healthcare Facilities (35), Preventative Care (32), Healthcare Professionals (20) |

The **eight community pillars** framing the discussion were: Storytelling, Quality of Life, Tourism, Economic Development, Talent Development, Public Health, Housing, and Infrastructure.

---

### 7. CONSENSUS RATES

- **Over half of all ideas (2,370 statements)** had an agreement rate of **over 80%**
- One source reported that **60% of ideas had agreement rates above 80%** (per Gorman)
- The AI pilot reportedly **boosted community input nearly 80-fold** compared to traditional engagement methods (per Jigsaw)
- 80% of participants found common ground on economic growth strategies
- Residents from **both ends of the political spectrum** concurred on mental health resources and sustainable development

**Seven statements with the strongest community consensus:**
1. Family-friendly activities
2. County-wide development
3. Grocery stores
4. Connecting downtown to the riverfront
5. Sidewalks & walkability
6. Alleviating traffic on Scottsville Road
7. Flooding & disaster preparedness

**Cross-partisan consensus areas** (surprising agreement across political divides):
- Parks and green spaces
- Housing affordability
- Mental health resources
- Sustainable development
- Bringing healthcare specialists to Bowling Green (to reduce travel to Nashville)
- Preserving historic buildings
- Prioritizing existing retail spaces over new construction

---

### 8. QUOTES FROM LEADERS AND ORGANIZERS

**Doug Gorman** (Warren County Judge-Executive):
- "What we just conducted was the largest town hall in America."
- "Are we going to solve every problem, no. But if we don't make a plan for 2050, it will go to us and it will change."
- "[We] gained so much valuable data from the general public" and the project "blown up so much bigger than I ever imagined."

**Sam Ford** (Innovation Engine co-founder):
- "Do we want this to happen to us, or for us. If we want it to happen for us, we have to have a plan."
- "AI provides ability to save time and handle bigger scale... find patterns hard for human eye to detect."

**Amanda Havard** (Innovation Engine co-founder):
- "The heart of this campaign is about trying to go to where people already gather."

**Yasmin Green** (Jigsaw CEO):
- Described Jigsaw's mission as to "figure out how to help us stay in the conversation together."

**Scott Carpenter** (Jigsaw Managing Director):
- "It's basically, in some ways, Google Maps of conversation."

**Daniel Tarnagda** (community participant):
- "If you don't ask, you don't know... one of the best ways to bring people more together."

**Laura Torres** (community participant):
- Survey accessibility meant "you didn't have to physically be somewhere to have your voice heard."

**Rep. Brett Guthrie:**
- "Technology may expose coarseness, but we can also use it to bring closeness."

**A participant quote:**
- "We discovered we're more alike than we thought."

---

### 9. HOW RESULTS WERE USED FOR STRATEGIC PLANNING

- Project volunteers were set to **deliver policy recommendations** to Warren County leadership in **late 2025**
- The Warren County Fiscal Court was **already implementing ideas** by summer 2025, including approving a **$5 million investment to create a unified fire department** (consolidating nine volunteer fire departments under one system)
- Judge-Executive Gorman committed to **implementing as many approved ideas as quickly as possible**, with constituents monitoring progress
- A **time capsule** was buried on April 15, 2025, to be opened in 25 years
- The report was designed to serve as the foundational **vision document** charting the course from the present to 2050
- After participating, **70% of people reported they felt more confident that their voice matters** on important issues affecting Bowling Green
- The budget for the initiative was reported at **under $10,000**

**Referenced inspirational models** from the community included: City Museum (St. Louis), Crystal Bridges (Bentonville), Brightline Rail (Florida), Red Rocks Amphitheater (Colorado), The Gathering Place (Tulsa), and bike trail networks from multiple cities.

---

### 10. NATIONAL EXPANSION: "WE THE PEOPLE"

The success of "What Could BG Be?" inspired a **national expansion** called **"We The People"**, unveiled in November 2025 by the **Napolitan Institute** in partnership with Jigsaw. This initiative:

- Surveys five participants in each of **435 congressional districts**
- Asks citizens about their understanding of freedom and equality
- Uses an **AI chatbot** to generate deeper responses (averaging **140 words** versus a typical 8-word survey response)
- Categorizes responses into **26 "ideals"** for broader agreement/disagreement analysis
- First report launching within weeks of announcement, with continued rollouts through **July 4, 2026** (the U.S. 250th anniversary)

**Scott Rasmussen** (Napolitan CEO) said: "At 140 words, you begin to hear people's thoughts and connections."

---

### 11. JIGSAW'S "FACILITATION IN THE AI ERA" REPORT

Published by Jigsaw in **October 2025**, this report is titled "Facilitation in the AI Era: A Community Roadmap for Technologies to Support Group Dialogue." It was led by researchers **Ian Beacock** and **Emily Saltz** at Jigsaw, based on an ethnographic study with **22 facilitators** representing a range of geographies, organizations, and traditions.

The report identifies **five untapped, high-value opportunity areas** for AI to support facilitators:

1. **Scaled Access** -- Multilingual communications and tailored outreach; translation features for language and cultural context; multimodal tools (audio, video, text) for improved participation and recruitment

2. **Dynamic Learning** -- Multimodal education and evidence features; tools for evidence discovery to help participants engage more deeply with topics

3. **Live Sensemaking** -- Real-time conversation analysis and visualization; tools to help facilitators quickly understand evolving conversations, provided tools can be trained on specific conversation nuances and participants have chances to review or challenge AI summaries

4. **Futurecasting** -- Scenario planning and tradeoff extrapolation tools; helping groups imagine and plan for future possibilities

5. **Sensemaking For The People** -- Interactive public-facing analysis and reporting; making conversation outcomes accessible to both participants and decision-makers

**Important caveat from the report:** These opportunity areas and accompanying design visualizations are **not products that Jigsaw is actively working on or necessarily planning to create**, but rather are "offered as potential inspiration for others to build on." All opportunities should be explored in partnership with facilitators and publics, to build trust in the technology and ensure it augments transformational dialogue.

The findings report was **authored collaboratively** by the facilitators from the original study and the Jigsaw researchers.

The full PDF is available at: https://services.google.com/fh/files/blogs/jigsaw_facilitation_in_the_ai_era.pdf

---

### Sources:

- [Jigsaw Medium: How one of the fastest-growing cities in Kentucky used AI to plan for the next 25 years](https://medium.com/jigsaw/how-one-of-the-fastest-growing-cities-in-kentucky-used-ai-to-plan-for-the-next-25-years-3b70c4fd1412)
